text: was a after Jōgen and before Kempo. This period started in March 1211 and ended in December 1213.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Kenryaku" in Japan encyclopedia, p. 510. The reigning emperor was .Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du Japon, pp. 230-238; Brown, Delmer. (1979). Gukanshō, pp. 341; Varley, H. Paul. (1980). Jinnō Shōtōki, pp. 221-223. ==Events of the Kenryaku era== * 1211 (Kenryaku 1, 1st month): The Buddhist priest Hōnen returned from a period of exile. He was the founder of the temple- complex.Titsingh, p. 230. * 1211 (Kenryaku 1, 1st month): Shogun Sanetomo's position at court was raised to the 1st rank of the 3rd class. * 2 January 1211 (Kenryaku 1, 16th day of the 1st month): The former-Senior High Priest Jien (1155–1225) was appointed Tendai Abbot.Brown, p. 342. * 1212 (Kenryaku 1): Hōnen died at age 80.Titsigh, p. 231. ==Related pages == * Kamakura period ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Kenryaku 1st 2nd 3rd 1211 1212 1213 Preceded by: Jōgen Era or nengō: Kenryaku Succeeded by: Kempo Category:Japanese eras Category:13th-century establishments in Japan Category:1210s disestablishments in Japan Category:1210s establishments in Asia
title: Kenryaku
